message_1: A game starts with a pile of 50 stones. Two players alternate taking up either 3 or 4 stones from the pile. The player who takes the last stone wins. If the first move is made by Player 1, and both players play optimally, who would win the game?
message_2:
To determine who would win the game, we can analyze the game using a backward induction strategy. We will start by looking at the possible outcomes for the last few stones and work our way back to the beginning of the game.

If there are 1 or 2 stones left, neither player can win since they can only take 3 or 4 stones. If there are 3 or 4 stones left, the current player can take all the remaining stones and win.

Now, let's consider the case when there are 5 stones left. If the current player takes 3 stones, the other player will take the remaining 2 stones and win. If the current player takes 4 stones, the other player will take the remaining 1 stone and win. So, in this case, the current player will lose.

When there are 6 stones left, the current player can take 3 stones, leaving the other player with the losing position of 3 stones. So, the current player will win in this case.

When there are 7 stones left, the current player can take 4 stones, leaving the other player with the losing position of 3 stones. So, the current player will win in this case.

Now, let's consider the general case. If the current player is in a position with a multiple of 5 stones (i.e., 5, 10, 15, 20, etc.), they will lose since any move they make will leave the other player with a winning position (6 or 7 stones left). If the current player is in a position with a multiple of 5 plus 1 or 2 stones (i.e., 6, 7, 11, 12, 16, 17, etc.), they can make a move that leaves the other player with a multiple of 5 stones, which is a losing position.

Since 50 is a multiple of 5, Player 1 will be in a losing position at the start of the game. Therefore, if both players play optimally, Player 2 will win the game.
